Reviews.Title: Excellent LCD TV
Reviews.Author: Ian
Reviews.Content: Did a lot of research on TVs before I decided to get this one. Was not excited about the 120hz TVs; do not like the soap opera/camcorder motion. I was debating if I should get the internet options with the apps on the other models, but I have a PS3 so it wasnt worth paying for the extra features. So I got this 60hz LCD and I have no regrets! The picture this TV produces are amazing, especially on Blu Ray. I watched my New Zealand vacation videos on it and it really brings out the colors and makes my video look even more movie like. Avatar looks amazing on it as well. I got it for $640 and worth every dime.

Reviews.Title: This is THE entry level TV!
Reviews.Author: Owen
Reviews.Content: Upon breaking the LCD panel in my previous Samsung TV, the LN4065F, I sent myself to Amazon in quest of a new TV.  I wanted another Samsung, since their build and picture quality seem topnotch, but I also wanted something relatively entry-level as a cheap means of replacing my older TV.The Samsung LN40C530 delivers in both departments, and with astonishing results.  At under 700usd at the time of my purchase, this set provides an excellent picture with extremely rich colors.  There is no problem with backlight bleeding or color inconsistency either.  Compared to my older TV set, this one has more of a semi-glossy screen with some matte properties.  Most people would view a semi-matte screen bad over a very glossy screen, but the matte elements in the screen do a great job of ensuring the colors this panel provide are very deep and saturated in well-lit environments.  Having a very high contrast ratio helps a great deal of bit with color reproduction as well.  At its default settings, the picture's a a bit too sharp, so setting sharpness down to around 30s will produce more desirable/natural pictures.  Compared to my older TV, the sound seems to be lesser, and not as deep, so I manually had to go into its equalizer and raise the lower hz rates up a little to produce satisfying results.  This is fine for most people, but ones who play games under game mode for lower input lag are forced to use default audio, so they should think twice if sound is a big issue to them.  A year later after getting this TV, I've hooked up a pair of PSB speakers with a Dayton T-Amp to provide a boost in sound fidelity.This TV doesn't boast any of the newer technologies we see today in higher end TVs-- such as 120/240hz, or led backlighting with or without local dimming-- but this TV doesn't need them.  Almost all signals are capped at 60hz, and it's up to the TV's motion estimation interpolation to render false frames (which can sometimes lead to unwanted artifacts/effects)  True 120hz won't be taken full advantage of until everything is broadcasted at a native 120hz rate.  Led local dimming seems nice, but this TV already is very bright, and shows no signs of backlight bleeding (blacks could be a little blacker, but that can usually be fixed by setting HDMI black level to low-- if wanted)  Besides that, there's little reason to be a stickler for very deep blacks if the TV shows no sign of backlight bleeding/clouding.In terms of build quality, for an entry level TV, the LN40C530 looks and feels like a higher end tv.  The bezel is small and compact (as well as a slimmer depth than my old TV: 3.1inches compared to 3.8inches), while Samsung included a row of touch sensitive buttons on the bottom right-- very akin to Sony PS3's power/eject buttons.  One thing I am a bit disappointed in is the lack of Samsung's trademark lighting effect on the bottom center of the bezel, but the blown glass-like design of the clear plastic under the bottom bezel looks very nice.  Even though Samsung says this TV doesn't come with a touch of color feature, you can make out a very faint amount of red accent in the very bottom of the TV.  The remote is another letdown for me, as the general look to it is very cheep compared to my older model. Thankfully, the older remote works on this new TV as well.As for the general consensus: If you're in the market for an entry level HDTV with amazing picture, you need not look further than this great piece of kit Samsung has introduced.

Reviews.Title: All the research leads to Samsung!
Reviews.Author: Hilldy Shaw
Reviews.Content: I haven't bought a television in 13 years and I wanted to make sure I got one that would last me at least another decade without breaking the bank. I did my homework and waited patiently for a price dip on a Samsung, which all the reviewers say are the best. I picked this one up for just over $600 and I'm so happy with it! Personally, I'm not interested in the technology race--I just want great picture quality and a set that is reliable and easy to operate. That's precisely what this is, with a fair amount of bells and whistles to boot.

Reviews.Title: An excellent TV for an excellent price
Reviews.Author: David Riley "Engineer / Pedantic Word Dork"
Reviews.Content: Visually, this TV is excellent.  The colors are vibrant and on-target (no purple cast like I've seen on some lower-end LCD TVs) and there's no ghosting.  Like with any high-resolution TV without an expensive upscaler built in, regular definition sources (e.g. older DVD players and game consoles) look a little blocky.  You can fix this with a fancy upscaling circuit like you find in the more expensive A/V receivers, but otherwise it's something you'll find on every TV.The audio is pretty good for built-in speakers.  It certainly has more bass than our old tube TV did; built-in amplifier technology on the TVs has advanced considerably over the past 5 years or so.  The volume control seems a little odd, though, in that when it's quiet you have to nearly double the numeric volume before it's noticeably louder.  I wonder if it might be using a linear scale instead of a logarithmic one (decibels, for example, are logarithmic).  Still, decent built-in speakers; if you want really nice sound, you'll want an external receiver (which is probably true of any built-in TV speakers anywhere).  It has optical and analog audio out if you want to plug it into a cheaper stereo instead of finding a more expensive receiver unit and speakers, which is nice (the analog is in the form of a stereo miniplug (headphone jack), which you can either plug in directly or get an RCA jack Y-adaptor for most stereos).One of the HDMI jacks has a stereo miniplug linked to it for audio input so you can plug your DVI-capable computer in and pass the audio in through the analog jack (since many computers have DVI, which is easily and cheaply adapted to HDMI but does not carry audio content).  This is a nice feature if you have a media PC or plug your laptop in for photo shows, etc.One thing I wasn't such a fan of was the menu system.  Samsung has always made nice TVs, but I feel their menu system has always been a little clunky (my old roommate had an older model and it was almost the same).  This machine is at least pretty responsive when you push the buttons, unlike older ones which were a little sluggish, but the menu system goes far too deep and doesn't seem particularly well organized.  I still can't figure out how to turn off the dynamic contrast scaling; the menu says it's off, but black screens full of white text (like the credits after The Office) cause the contrast to adjust up and down, making the text a different brightness on each subsequent screen depending on how much white text there is.  Minor quibble, and it probably does improve the picture on the show itself, but still.And, like most LCD TVs these days, it takes about 5 seconds to turn on or off, which is puzzling for people when they hit the power button and nothing happens instantaneously.  This isn't unique to this TV or even Samsung TVs, of course, but if it's a surprise to you, don't panic.My chief complaint about the menu system is that you can really only select from a handful of preset names for each of the sources; items like "TV", "Game", "DVD", "DVR" and a few other assorted oddities.  I have a PS2, an XBox and a Wii; I guess I name them all "Game" and hope I can remember which input goes with which?  I also have the new AppleTV (which is wonderful), but the closest category that fits it (to my mind) was "IPTV".  This is somewhat superficial and not at all a dealbreaker, but it does occasionally confuse the less technical members of my household.  Given that it would have been trivial for their software engineers to add an option for specifying a custom name, it's a little disappointing.  I think I actually remember being able to do that on my old roommate's older Samsung TV, but maybe I'm misremembering.Last complaint: No S-Video input.  I'm probably part of a sub-1% group that finds this annoying, but I have several older game consoles which provide S-Video out and not component out, and their composite looks terrible (specifically the Super Nintendo).  I suppose I'll just have to wait until I get a real receiver, most of which do have S-Video inputs (and better upscaling).  I think I was just more surprised than anything else, since this is the first TV I've seen that doesn't have any S-Video inputs.All in all, I am 100% happy with this TV, and I can't say I've ever seen a modern-day HDTV with a reasonable menu system.  Make sure you measure your space before you pick the size, though!  I did, and 40" is the perfect size for us; my wife thought it sounded way too big, and we almost went with the 36" (which would have looked oddly small in the space it's in).  Eyeballing it is a good way to wind up with a TV that's too big (won't fit or overwhelms people at the viewing distance) or too small.And, of course, if you're looking for bells and whistles like 120 Hz (I don't really watch anything that takes advantage of it, so it seemed like a waste of money to me), you'll need to pick a higher-end model.

Reviews.Title: GREAT PICTURE AND GREAT REMOTE
Reviews.Author: W. G. Michel
Reviews.Content: I realize that this is probably a "guy thing" but this remote is the quickest responding remote of any flat screen I've seen.  It also has a "favorite" button where you can easily program it to just scan your favorite channels.  I got this TV for my mother and was so pleased with it, that I ordered another for myself before they change anything.  I'm really happy.  I've also bought the Western Digital TV Live device for $119 at Amazon.  This allows me to view my digital pictures on my 40" Samsung TV via the inexpensive $2.63 HDMI cable.  Wow!

Reviews.Title: Excellent buy for your money and great TV
Reviews.Author: Jennifer P. Jackson "projectx633"
Reviews.Content: We had a 52" Samsung that we purchased for my mother-in-law.  We've watched TV on it for 2 years and are extremely happy with it.  For this reason, we decided to stick with Samsung.  This 40" TV fits our space perfectly and after comparing a 60hz LCD HDTV side-by-side (playing the exact same nature DVD) with a 120hz, I did not notice any difference.  Since the 60hz was about $150 less, I decided on this TV.  We are extremely happy with it.We only watch TV -- we don't do gaming, watch DVDs, nor do we have a Blu-Ray.  So, we're pretty basic TV watchers.  The picture is excellent from all viewing angles -- no distortion.  My girlfriend came over 2 nights ago and wants to order a Samsung for her Mom. I don't think you can go wrong if you are basic TV watchers like us!  By the way, I'm not sure if I can say this here but I priced this TV at Walmart for $674.00 online, however, through Amazon, we didn't have to pay any shipping costs nor taxes!  Amazon, by far, had the least expensive price over Best Buy, Walmart and any other online merchant.  The delivery guys took the TV out of the box, set it up and made sure it did turn on.  They were great.  Getting it to sync up with Dish TV and the Dish Remote was another matter but 2 phone calls to Dish was all it took.  We had it up and running in an hour or so.  Excellent buying experience!

Reviews.Title: Basic features, but great picture
Reviews.Author: Sean U
Reviews.Content: Normally I wouldn't order an item this size from Amazon... but I had some gift cards and needed a tv for the bedroom. I already own an LN52B550 which I am happy with. I was deciding between this tv and the LG42LD450. I decided to pay the extra money and go with the Samsung.  The first TV arrived in a badly damaged box, and the TV had a crushed corner when I opened the box. I quickly filed a return request, and also got Amazon customer service to overnight the replacement (thanks Amazon!). While the damage was not Amazons fault, the packaging of the TV does not lend itself to shipping. There is very little protection from the thin Styrofoam packing, and while the second set arrived undamaged, the Styrofoam had cracked in shipping on the set as well.  If your tv arrives in cold weather, bring it inside to warm up to room temperature for a few hours, to reduce the chance of damage from condensation.  Setup of the TV is straight forward, there are lots of options in the menu, and everybody has different preferences, but I set up my TV as follows :  Backlight 6  Mode : Movie  Color Temp : Warm 2  Colorspace : auto  Sharpening : 0  All enhancements (Noise Reduction, edge enhancement, Mpeg NR etc) : offI have not had time to do a more thorough calibration, but with these settings, the picture is smooth and natural, while a little on the cool side. This can be tweaked, so its not a big deal.The remote control is not programmable, so I am using the remote from the Fios HD box for now. I will probably get a Harmony remote at some point as there a few hiccups with changing inputs with the Fios remote.This TV has a panel code of CN07... which is a lower end panel made by Chi Mei. I don't think you will be able to find this lower end set with a Samsung Panel. Viewing angles seem pretty good, color is good (needs some tweakes) and I don't see any back light leakage. I am not using the set for gaming, so i can't comment on lag. The good quality hd channels from Fios (History HD, Smithsonian) look great, and standard def content looks ok. I have an upscaling 1080p Samsung dvd player connected through HDMI, and high quality DVD's like Gladiator, Cars etc look great.The lcd is somewhere in between glossy and matte. I do notice the reflections of lights from in front of the tv, but the overhead lights don't show up. I personally like it better than the highly glossy screens on many sets.Sound is just ok in my opinion. Again, there is only so much you can squeeze into these LCD's, so it is pretty on par with what I expected. Stereo separation and bass response are lacking.I didn't get to do a side by side comparison with the 42" LG, so I can't comment on that set. I feel that at the current price, the Samsung is a good value.If you buy a Samsung TV, register it online at the Samsung site for an extension of the 1 year warranty. Samsung sets of this size are eligible for in-home warranty service.Overall, I like the TV. The red "touch of color" accents are very muted, and you probably won't even notice it if the room is not brightly lit. It's a nice sized, no-nonsense set that won't empty your bank account.

Reviews.Title: Excellent television for a family w/out some Fancy HD system
Reviews.Author: travelerofnj
Reviews.Content: Purchased this specific model based on the recommendation by Consumers Report.  After 24 yrs of following their recommendations for cars, household appliances and smaller goods, they have never steered me wrong.  Samsung is excellent television thus far.  Good price, easy to set up and sync'd w/ our cable system quickly.  We have not used all the features yet, but on the HD channels the clarity, richness of detail and color is outstanding.  Son even plays his Wii games on the set and the large screen gives you more a sense of being in the game.  Since we have small children (5 and 7) and fear one of them crashing into the set, we tethered the set into the wall studs, rather than a wall mount.Delivery was as per projected.  Box probably weighed 45-50 lbs and the set-up to the stand was simple.  Would buy this unit again and from the same Amazon vendor.

Reviews.Title: Great TV, beautiful picture, awesome value
Reviews.Author: foslock
Reviews.Content: I got this TV as a replacement for a faulty LG 37LD450 I had gotten for my dorm room. This is obviously of much higher build quality.The picture is terrific, whites are clearly white, and the blacks are very black (no blue/gray tinting). The audio is nice, for TV speakers, but I use an external system (this model DOES have a 3.5mm external audio output) so I have no complaints.The one thing that I wish I would have known is that it doesn't actually have a swivel stand, as far as I can tell. It doesn't rotate at all if I try to turn the TV (thought it might just be stuck, but I've pushed as hard as I want to without risking damage).Also, just because I think this might annoy some people, when you mute the TV, the little mute graphic stays and sort of dances (slowly) around the left of the screen until you unmute it. It does not disappear with time. This might annoy some people (gamers especially) but you can still just turn the volume down to 0, or "hard" mute it in the options menu, neither of which will display that annoying little box.Those are the only two things that bug me though, and overall I would definitely recommend this TV to anyone looking for a solid 40". THE 40" IS CHEAPER THAN THE 37" RIGHT NOW, SO DON'T BUY THAT ONE! Also, I think you get in-home service with TVs that are 40" and larger, not with 37".Also, I'd like to note that PS3 games look fantastic on this TV, even though it still is in the 60hz camp. Personally, I don't think 120hz is worth the extra $100, especially after seeing what this TV can do,

Reviews.Title: Another awesome Samsung TV
Reviews.Author: Luci Blace
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic TV. Super sharp, great color, good contrast. My only nitpicks: 1) The audio is very average 2) The startup/shutdown chime is very loud and I can't find anywhere to disable it and 3) The default picture settings are bizarre (see below)I was seeing tons of image artifacts and streaking. I was seeing what looked like crappy MPEG4 compression artifacts in an HD recording. I went digging in the advanced video menu and found a "Movie Mode" setting as well as a couple of noise reduction algorithms that were all turned on by default. Once I disabled them, the TV came alive! Now the picture is crisp and bright. I don't know why they would turn on a bunch of noise reduction algorithms that make HD streams look worse when 90% of what people will be watching will be > 720p...I'm very happy with the TV, but wondering how many less technologically inclined people are watching this TV and wondering why the picture looks muddy and streaky.

Reviews.Title: better than expected
Reviews.Author: vickiegasm
Reviews.Content: I've been wanting an HDTV for myself for a long time and did quite a bit of research. and i always knew i wanted to go with a samsung. since amazon is having some sales right now, i decided to go ahead and buy this on a whim. and i'm glad i did.the clarity is amazing! my xbox 360 has never looked so good. even when i play old dvds it looks more clear than before.i was expecting the audio to be not so good since i read a lot of reviews complaining about it. i guess they must be used to having a surround sound because the audio sounds really good to me. i don't even go higher than 20 on the volume because the sound travels so well.i'm overall extremely happy with my new hdtv. one of the best purchases of my life.

Reviews.Title: Great flat screen TV
Reviews.Author: andes744
Reviews.Content: I bought this flat screen TV to replace a 720p flatscreen for FIOS HDTV for my living room.  I wanted a larger screen and full HD at 1080p.  It is connected in a standard way (HDMI) to the FIOS box and I'm using the built in speakers.  I also use it for BluRay video DVD's.  I am very happy with the TV and the overall quality of the picture, the colors, and the resolution.  The remote is pretty easy to use, the setup is easy to use, and the connections are good.  I am using the included stand for the TV.  The picture is plenty bright, the resolution is great, the colors look good, and so far, no complaints.  I also occasionally use it for my computer as a giant computer screen, which works fine.  A couple of nice features for this TV is that it seems to know when the BluRay is on and switches to that input.  Also you can connect a thumb drive/memory stick to view photos or videos.  Oveall, this is a very nice flat screen TV.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Andrew
Reviews.Content: This TV is everything I needed for the gaming and sports viewing experience.  The definition is awesome and I couldn't ask for anything more.  Definitely worth every cent!

Reviews.Title: great Amazon Service
Reviews.Author: Cynthia Nill
Reviews.Content: The Freight service that Amazon used to deliver the 40 inch Samsung TV was outstanding. They called the day before delivery to confirm their delivery date, then they called on the delivery date to confirm a two hour delivery period.  The gentlemen who delivered the TV took it out of the box, set the TV up and disposed of the box.  Top notch service.  The TV picture and sound quality are outstanding. Couldn't be happier with my purchase; the price, the value for the money and the quality of the television have all met or exceeded my expectations.Samsung LN40C630 40-Inch 1080p 120 Hz LCD HDTV (Black)

Reviews.Title: Worked okay for 2 years, but then....
Reviews.Author: LMP
Reviews.Content: We bought this TV about 2 years ago and it was working fine until last week when it started taking longer for it to turn on. The sound up start would stop and start as if it was trying to come on, but then it would take several minutes for it to actually turn on.  When I began looking online for possible causes,I saw that MANY people were having the same issue as us and eventually the tv would just not turn on at all. It seems as though many of the Samsung tv's have an issue with the capacitors not working correctly or being defective and that they were having them repaired at no cost if that was the case. Of course when I called about our tv, the person at Samsung said it would be covered but then they didn't put that on the electronic form that the repair company receives so I had to call back and sit on hold again...this time they tell me that my tv is not covered...so I asked to speak to a supervisor. I get put on hold again and after explaining the situation to her, she puts me on hold and then comes back and says there's nothing she can do since our model was not one of the ones covered to fix the defect. "Why did they even bother sending me to you?" I asked her and she then sent me to someone else who could possibly help me. Once again, I explained the problem, he put me on hold and then came back and said that we can have someone come out to look at it and if it is the capacitors they will repair them for free, if it's not that, then we're on our own for the bill. They are coming Monday and they better hope for their sake that it's the capacitors....talk about giving me the runaround!! A two year old tv should not go bad that fast but I guess that's what these companies hope for is that you get fed up and just go buy a new one....well, I can tell you right now that I won't be buying anymore Samsungs!!

Reviews.Title: Great for the money
Reviews.Author: Instructional Designer
Reviews.Content: I went back and forth debating a 32 inch, 40 inch, or 46 inch. In the end I decided, that when I move it would need to be able to fit in my car, so that ruled out the 46 inch. Of course, you should always buy the biggest tv then that you can afford (you never hear somebody complain that they bought too big of a tv, it's usually the reverse), so that narrowed it down to 40 inches. I was shopping over Black Friday and almost let myself be swayed by the super low priced tvs. Fortunately I realized that I was then giving up many of the features that really did matter to me. Such as plenty of av, hdmi, computer inputs. What household only needs one input? Ha, between the blu ray, wii, and computer, I already needed at least 3 (plus if I'm like any good American consumer, I'll continue to accumulate toys). In the end, this tv had all the features I was looking for, from the ability to toggle audio and video quality to inputs for all my toys. Sure I could have splurged and gotten an internet ready tv, but what purchase would that have served. I don't need another excuse to stay put in front of my tv for long periods of time. I want to be able to enjoy a movie with good audio and video quality, then get up and getting moving.

Reviews.Title: We love it!
Reviews.Author: Katrina G. "Soul Child"
Reviews.Content: We've had our TV for a little over a month now, and we absolutely love it. Can't really say anything bad about it. The colors are amazing, and the picture for it here on Amazon DOES NOT do it justice. Blu-Ray is phenomenal for this TV. In fact, it's comparable to an IMAX screen, just much much smaller.  For those that got a TV that instantly stopped working, you can't expect EVERY TV to come out perfect. There are going to be defective models in the system somewhere, but that's no reason to condemn the entire brand or model. It's like buying a car made on a Friday; there's going to be things wrong with it. But that doesn't mean that EVERY car like it sucks and will be problematic.  One random thing I've noticed is this... on an older TV everything, including actors and actresses, look absolutely flawless. They look perfect. So do props, and animations. However, on a High Def TV you can see the little imperfections everywhere, on everyone, that remind you that yes the celebrities are still just people too.~** UPDATE ** ~ June 2012  Still in perfect working order, no problems whatsoever. The quality still impresses. We're considering buying an HDMI cable, but it's hard to imagine an improvement since the quality really is excellent. Certainly exceeded our expectations for the brand and the price (I've always been a devotee to Sony). WORTH THE BUY.

Reviews.Title: Samsung LN40C530
Reviews.Author: kurtjwaz
Reviews.Content: You cannot go wrong with Samsung.  Picture is crystal clear, and surprisingly the sound quality is very good.  I also own a 55" Toshiba Regza which privides a comparable picture but sound quality suffers.I would not hesitate to buy Samsung again!

Reviews.Title: Great TV, yet not marvellous
Reviews.Author: deepac
Reviews.Content: This is a great TV. I am a SAMSUNG fan, and I have 3 other HD SAMSUNG TVs in my house, we got this TV through AMAZON, the video quality is just great, but the audio quality is not comparable to my 42 inch SAMSUNG. I guess they really raise the volumes in TVs starting at 42 inches, but this 40 inch TV has good stereo sound, but is not good enough for a room bigger than 15 feet distance from your position. Other than this, I like the style, performance and cost. Thanks

Reviews.Title: Samsung Shines
Reviews.Author: Richard H. Nelson Jr.
Reviews.Content: My Third LCD TV. I also have a 42 inch and a 37 inch LG. I purchased this one for the bedroom. Quite simply for the price this TV is super. Does all the basics very well...Perfect picture...Great sound and very easy to set up....You may pay alittle more for a Samsung....but beieve me...well worth it

Reviews.Title: Great Overall TV
Reviews.Author: Jeff
Reviews.Content: Awesome picture without HDMI cables. Will be even better when they arrive. The sound is amazing and speakers very loud. TV itself is sharp looking, you will not be dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: This tv rocks, had it two months now
Reviews.Author: mark
Reviews.Content: Wow is all I can say, I have a small living room and this 40 inch is amazing.  Looked at a bunch in this size range and nothing beat it for clarity options and the price was ok, there were cheaper but the 80000-1 contrast sold me, the others had all the same stuff mostly but this one had this and more HDMI connections and my games are rocking on it.  Cant go wrong in my opinion and when i move this is bedroom bound and ill get the 46 or larger version of this guy for sure.Happy tv hunting

Reviews.Title: Pretty Sweet
Reviews.Author: Zam Tual "ztual"
Reviews.Content: I've had this TV for about a day now and I really like it. My roomie played COD:MW2 for like 6 hours straight on the first day I got it. Picture is awesome and am very happy with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Completely Satisfied!
Reviews.Author: Bob Kerpec, Sr
Reviews.Content: This is my second Samsung hdtv, the other a 53" purchased about 5 years ago.  This television was very easy to set up, exhibits surprisingly good audio and video quality and has performed flawlessly, as would be expected.  I have been using it for about a month now and am completely satisfied.  I would recommend it to anyone seeking a reasonably priced hdtv with high expectations for video and audio quality.  Also I was again pleasantly surprised with the timeliness of Amazon arranged delivery.  Nice job, Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Purchase!
Reviews.Author: Freedom
Reviews.Content: This is my third Samsung TV, and it's definitely the best one yet.  The picture is exceptional, really good sound quality, and the TV is very attractive.  The set-up was simple, and the programming was fast and self-explanatory. After researching for several weeks, this was the best TV for the best price.

Reviews.Title: Great TV for the price
Reviews.Author: Leonidas Fegaras
Reviews.Content: I had a 32-inch LCD Samsung before, but this is far better. The most amazing feature is its USB port, which strangely is not highlighted very well in the Amazon description. I am guessing that all new LCD TVs have this USB port now. It can actually play most mpeg-4 movies (such as .avi movies), including high-definition encodings with high bitrates and the quality is excellent. It can also embed subtitles to the movies if the .sub files (or other formats) are in the same directory and have the same file name. Instead of a USB memory key, you can also connect a self-powered USB disk to the USB port as long as it's formatted in VFAT or NTFS.

Reviews.Title: Nice to have HD flat screen TV
Reviews.Author: Barbara Maller "Barbara Maller"
Reviews.Content: The audio and video are great. Changing from one mode to another can test ones agility and quickness.All-in-all, however, it is a lovely set with a great picture.

Reviews.Title: OUTSTANDING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Enrique
Reviews.Content: I ordered this TV a month ago and it is so awesome and worth every penny. I love to watch movies and for those of you who do, you can load your favorite family videos or movies on a thumb drive or external hard drive and watch all of your movies, photos and slide shows as well as listen to music. The connect share feature makes having to get a DVD player almost obsolete. Playing my PlayStation 3 on my LN40C530 LCD TV is jaw dropping and the sound is unbelievable.If you are looking for a LCD TV with the rite bells and whistles then the LN40C530 LCD is the one for you.One of the best purchases I have ever made.

Reviews.Title: Great buy
Reviews.Author: b-gat
Reviews.Content: The picture and audio on this set are comparable to higher-priced models, it has all the features I can imagine myself needing, and it's snazzy-looking.  I use this for an HTPC set-up (I don't have cable, so I just watch Netflix streamed through a desktop PC tower, Blu-ray discs, and Hulu), and for gaming with my Xbox 360.  It has all the ports I need, and it seems to work well with all my various devices.A word on gaming: The 60 Hz refresh rate works well with my 360, so I haven't seen any lag time in controller input or even had to calibrate my Rock Band games, as I expected I would.  I'm disappointed that the graphics don't really look much or at all better to me on this TV than they did on my old standard definition set (even after adjusting the console settings appropriately, and yes, I'm using an HDMI cable), but I don't think that's the TV's fault.  I've tried the 360 on other HDTVs and been similarly underwhelmed.  In any case, it's nice to have a big screen, and I'm glad I didn't have to fiddle around with the settings on the TV to make it work.

Reviews.Title: Great TV--Very Happy
Reviews.Author: Baloowater
Reviews.Content: Thanks to careful reading of many reviews for various tv's--it can be so overwhelming--I finally decided to take the plunge and I have not been sorry!!  This TV works great, looks great and is picture perfect out of the box.  I will say I purchased the WI-FI stick separate and now that I am all hooked up, I am in heaven.  I put this tv in my bedroom where I happily stream movies from netflix and watch my shows on my computer I have hooked up to it.  Yes, even with internet apps, I had to hook a computer to it because low and behold HULU requires a subscription and it does not carry all the shows HULU on the computer does.  I found that very disappointing.  I like to watch CBS, NBC,ABC,FOX episodes of shows I miss.  HULU on the internet apps carried very few. However you hook up the computer to it and the catching up begins. So everything with TV is fabulous--internet apps not all useful--only netflix.  It does have Cinema now, but the movies are $4.00 a piece.All in all, internet apps not really necessary once you have a computer hooked to it--that's all you need.  Might be able to save a bit going with just PC hookup.Maybe they will upgrade the internet apps to be more useful one day.

Reviews.Title: Transformers DVD 43:30
Reviews.Author: B. May
Reviews.Content: Good morning. First I'd like to say that overall, I'm very pleased with the quality of the TV. After much reasearch it can down to this Samsung and the Sony EX400. I chose this for the price (I got it for 549USC as opposed to the Sony EX400 that was going for 599usc at the same store). I thought, the build quality for this TV was better and I like the swivel stand.  After some fine tuning the colors are accurate, the sound passable (however setting the TV at 100 sound level is not 4 times louder them 25%), but thats ok as this TV is in my bedroom and I rarely need to set the sound to louder then 30.  My setup is this TV connected via HDMI to my PS3 slim. Most movies I watch are in the TV's setup to game mode (zero lag). The only problem I have seen in a moth of warching OTA HD TV, Blu Rays and DVD are Sweeny Todd Blu ray which has slightly notable motion blur in dark fast scenes and in Transformers DVD at 43:30 which is a fast moving action scene. There is ghosting when the a10's manuver and the banking AWACS aircraft. Otherwise for video games (all types) I have not noticed the problem.  Mostly I game on my Xbox 360 in the living room on a 2 yr old Samsung plasma so its not much of a problem. Just thought I'd bring it to your attention..Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: HOW TO FIX THE FLICKER PROBLEM
Reviews.Author: Tony NYC "Tony NYC"
Reviews.Content: If you browse the web, you will see that many owners of this and other Samsung 530 series TV's have a problem where the TV no longer works properly and all you get is a FLICKERING on the screen.I did a LOT of research on line and found one guy who stated that he had the same problem with his 46" Samsung set.Well, he posted that Samsung didn't want to know about the problem since his warranty is up. Then I found that MANY people had the same problem AFTER the warranty was up. So, when I experienced this problem, I figured, what did I have to lose to try his fix.If you open the back of the set, you will see a circuit board. there are two, but we are only concerned with the yellowish colored circuit board NOT the green one. This is the power supply board. On this board, you will see many "jumpers". They are little strips of metal, like wire, that come out of one hole in the board and go straight to another hole in the board. The jumpers are numbered. If you look for jumper JP852 you have found the right one. Once you have found it, CLIP this piece of metal, push the two ends away from each other and this should do the trick. It worked for me, but I'm only suggesting this if you are OUT of warranty and don't want to pay a technician to fix it. UNPLUG THE SET before doing this.I found this info on line and did it to my out of warranty Samsung model LN40C530 it's a 40 inch set.From what I read, this circuit has something to do with the auto brightness and contrast feature that lets the TV adjust itself depending on the brightness of the room. I never used that feature anyway, but when it goes, it gives you FLICKERING regardless of whether you have this feature activated or not. So, what the heck, my TV works perfectly again, and I can still adjust brightness and contrast.I'm glad I did a little research on the web. I fixed it for free and trust me, it was VERY easy. Just be sure to look at the board carefully, find the JP852 jumper, clip it and push the two pieces of metal away from each other so they don't touch.Another person who had the same problem found out how to fix this by watching the technician who he had to pay to fix the set.In my opinion, Samsung MUST know about this problem since it's all over the internet. Do a search for Samsung Flickering and you will see plenty of complaints. The guy who had the problem with the 46 inch set shows you how to fix it for that set. The board is different, but its' the SAME jumper. JP852. I believe I found that fix on CNET.DO NOT FORGET TO UNPLUG THE SET before doing this. and use a nail clipper to clip the jumper. I am NOT certain that this will work on every set, BUT, it worked for me and it worked for many others who have this set and other sets of the same series.I was really pissed off at Samsung for not offering a fix for this problem since SO MANY people had the same problem, but it IS a great set and I'm glad it's working again.UNPLUG THE SET SO THAT YOU DO NOT GET A SHOCK!

Purchased March 2011, and everything was fine until December 2011, when an annoying flickering/strobe-like light began - but not all the time.  And with no apparent reason (when I first turned the TV on, or sometimes when the TV was on for some time, in the morning, at night, when it was above freezing outside, when it was below freezing outside).  In other words, I was held hostage by the TV as to when it wanted to act up.  To top this all off, Samsung tells me it's no longer under warranty.  I expected much more for my money than 8 months of viewing without problems.

The sound and picture are amazing. I initially wanted a 42 inch TV but it was worth sacrificing the additional 2 inches for such phenomenal picture quality. There are so many bells and whistles, a large remote for big fingers and hands, the jingle when the TV is turned on or off, the ability to change picture size and sound from the remote without having to go into the menu just to name a few. The only negative I can think of is the floating mute icon on the left hand side which when engaged can be a little distracting but how often do you use the mute button. Amazon had the BEST price and with no tax or shipping fee I saved a bundle. I LOVE THIS TV. So if you are on the fence like I was go for it...you will not be disappointed. Big kuddos to Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Waited, waited, waited-- and then jumped...
Reviews.Author: M.Jacobs
Reviews.Content: What do they call that? -- paralysis by analysis, yeah, ya'll been there. SO many opinions, so much information, all those stats, and suddenly you find yourself silently judging your friends' TV's with your hard-won knowledge of refresh rates and sub-pixels. The good thing, of course, is that as you've been sitting on the sidelines pouring over your handwritten notes and printouts of three-page-long blog posts from a five-star-propeller-head who hasn't seen daylight since the Atari 2600 was released, TV prices have gone down and features have gone up. This TV was twice this price a year-and-a-half ago...and, after recently buying it, I can honestly say it is STILL WORTH what it USED TO cost!Are you kidding me-- $550 for this TV? It's like buying a brand new Lamborghini with whatever's in the lint-laden coin jar on top of your dresser. It's an insanely beautiful TV, the picture is amazing, and there are plenty of inputs for someone like me-- most particularly the USB input-- LOVE IT-- just pop your .AVI/.WAV/.MP3, etc. files onto a USB flash drive and plunk it into the port-- and you're off and watching movies, listening to music, or enjoying an instant slide show of your stupid friend's drunken disaster of a wedding.But the final push to this TV was when I actually EXPERIENCED all that I'd been reading about the "all important" Hz refresh rate. Yes, this TV only has a 60 Hz refresh rate (oh, that's so 2009!!), while newer, pricier TV's sport 120 Hz or now 240 Hz. But when I saw the 120 and the 240 Hz TV's, the picture was beautifully horrible. The images were so clear and the colors so vivid and precise that it actually decreased my viewing pleasure rather then enhance it. Strange, right!? But yes, suddenly I'm thinking to myself-- "Oh man, look at the pocks marks on Nicolas Cage's face" or "Jeez, just how do they get that much makeup on you everyday Oprah?!" or "Please let me believe that these people are actually riding off into a perfect desert sunset and not sitting on a mechanical horse, in a Hollywood sound-stage, and staring at a giant painted backdrop." The picture is soooooo real that it strips away the illusion of the movies. Who wants THAT?! Not me, oy vey!It turns out that not only is the Samsung LN40C530 the TV that I'd been waiting for all along, but because I had such a chronic case of "paralysis by analysis", the poor TV actually had to wait on me to get smart enough to appreciate it.

Reviews.Title: Just OK
Reviews.Author: The Professor
Reviews.Content: I bought the TV on Amazon. Competitive price, free shipping. Delivery was supposed to take 7-10 days. It took 2 1/2. Setup was fairly easy, but assembling the stand was tricky. The stand is not pre-threaded so you have to be careful to insert the screws straight when driving them in. They are difficult to tighten sufficiently to prevent rocking when the TV is attached. If you are small in stature, you need help with attaching the TV to the stand. The 40" size is about perfect for my small apt. -- The picture is much better than I'm used to (my old TV was 16 yrs old). Sound is pretty good, but varies in volume depending on the signal. Off air is very good, CD player signal requires cranking up the sound. I wish it had analog sound output so I could hook it up to my old stereo. -- My rube-goldberg TV antenna works fairly well, but requires lots of adjustments depending on the day or the weather. -- A minor problem is that sometimes the channel favorites pop off fave status. It seems to happen sometimes when I'm trying to tune a particulary weak signal.  Most of the time when reception is good faves stay on the list. - UPDATE:  The remote suddenly stopped working.  Changing batteries did not help, but I later found that one of them was dead despite being new.  When the new remote arrived, it initially didn't work either.  After about 10 minutes of trying, the new remote started working with the old remote batteries.  ???? Then the old remote resumed working.While not a total disappointment, I would not be averse to trying another brand.  I've changed my rating to 2 from 3.  I would give it a 2 1/2 if I had the option.  Maybe TV performance would improve with a cable hookup.

Reviews.Title: Good Quality - Annoying Oddities
Reviews.Author: Nikolai Verian
Reviews.Content: I purchased this television as my first HD television ever. I was amazed by the video quality once I hooked it up with HDMI cables and I have no complaints with the quality of picture or sound. However, from the get-go, I've had problems with this television. It takes almost 30 seconds for it to start up and sometimes I have to press power 4-5 times in order to turn it on. Other times, when it does turn on, there's a gray screen and I have to restart it several times to get a picture.The television's response time in regard to the remote is slow. I also find that it does not like to cooperate very well with my DVR's remote.I ended up returning this television.
